In circumstances where there is a fixed term contract of employment, one of the factors to be taken into account when considering the reasonableness of the restrictive covenant is whether it is temporally proportionate to the term of the employment. The judge observed that while there are plenty of examples of cases in which eighteen month or two year restrictive covenants for senior employees in positions comparable to Kerzner's had been deemed by courts to be reasonable, none of those decisions involved fixed term employment contracts for a relatively short term of employment. The judge concluded that AIM could not have it both ways. It was unreasonable for an employer in the position of AIM to insist on a fixed term arrangement, yet simultaneously restrain Kerzner from working elsewhere in the only business he had been involved in for the past 35 years, for a period of time that, in the case of the non-solicitation restriction, was for the same length of time as the employment contract itself.[93]

Kerzner's acknowledgement that the defendant required protection of its legitimate business interest was a factor to be taken into consideration. However, the judge concluded that read and considered in the context of a short, fixed-term contract with unreasonably broad geographic restrictions, and even allowing for the fact that the 2014 Employment Agreement provided Kerzner with an entitlement to compensation upon termination that was more generous than his statutory entitlement, the non-competition and non-solicitation clauses were unreasonable and, hence, unenforceable.[94]

AIM's statement of defence and counterclaim requested a declaration that Kerzner breached his fiduciary obligations to AIM by commencing employment with a competitor in November 2015. No particulars of Kerzner's alleged breach of his fiduciary obligations were pleaded, but a clue could be found in a paragraph addressing damages which referred to confidential and proprietary information having been taken and/or used by Kerzner.[95]

The judge accepted the basic premise that Kerzner's fiduciary responsibilities did not automatically end with his employment. The assertion that the taking up of employment with Palmer was in breach of his fiduciary responsibilities was harder to sustain given the finding that the restrictive covenants were unenforceable. Kerzner scrupulously refrained from soliciting any and all customers of AIM. Beyond the bald assertion in the counterclaim that AIM had been damaged by its confidential and proprietary information having been taken or used by Kerzner, AIM presented no evidence to the contrary. The record was insufficient to support any finding that Kerzner breached any continuing fiduciary obligations he may have had to AIM.[96]

In Cosolo v. Geo. A. Kelson Limited,[97] the Plaintiff engineer was employed by the Defendant engineering firm between 2005 and October 30, 2015 and ultimately achieved the position of Vice President, Supply Chain & Procurement. Throughout the plaintiff's employment, there was no written employment contract. At the time of his departure, the Plaintiff was one of the five senior executives of the firm. The Plaintiff was approached by an executive recruiter, a “head-hunter,” seeking to secure a Chief Executive Officer for a small mechanical contractor that the firm sometimes used as a sub-contractor for the supply of sheet medal. It shortly became a part of ENGIE which was a large global engineering firm and a direct competitor of the firm. ENGlE had approximately 150,000 employees worldwide. During his employment, he acquired and sold 43,000 Class E common shares of the firm for $891,820, for which he was to receive ten installment payments of $89,182 plus interest on the outstanding balance. He received the first installment before his employment ended, but in 2016, after he was no longer an employee and had become the CEO of a rival engineering firm, the installments stopped. The firm refused to make further payments and it alleged that he had breached his fiduciary duties and asserted by way of defence a right of setoff for damages from the breach of fiduciary duty.[98]

The motions judge described the law associated with the fiduciary duties of a departing senior executive who is not also bound by a written employment contract that might restrict his or her rights to compete against the former employer. A departing servant has the right to compete with his former employer and he or she may bring to that business the knowledge and skill acquired while in the former service, including knowledge and skill directly obtained from the previous employer. Further, the departing employee may solicit business from the former employer's customers provided that: (a) there is no valid restrictive clause preventing him or her from doing so; (b) the departing employee does not use material obtained or retained in fraud of the employer; and (c) the departing employee does not misappropriate the employer's confidential information. Where the departing employee is also a fiduciary of the employer, he or she may not directly solicit the former employer's customers for the reasonable period of time necessary to enable the former employer to retain the loyalty of the customers and to ameliorate the disruption caused by the fiduciary's departure. The duration and the extent to which fiduciary obligations continue after an employee with fiduciary obligations departs is determined on a case by case basis and depends upon a matrix of factors. After employment ends, the fiduciary employee generally cannot directly solicit the employer's customers for a reasonable period of time, but in the absence of a restrictive covenant, the fiduciary is free to otherwise compete once his or her employment ends, provided that he does not do so unfairly. The law, however, is cautious in imposing restrictive duties on departing employees in less than clear circumstances because of the public interest in free competition and the public policy of allowing citizens the freedom to pursue economic advantage through mobility in employment. After the termination of the fiduciary relationship, competition, as such, is not prohibited because the law does not favour restraints on trade or impeding a person's ability to make a living. Rather, the prohibitions focus on the manner of the competition, which must be fair and honourable. The former fiduciary may accept orders from former clientele of the employer, but the former fiduciary may not directly solicit that trade until a reasonable period of time has elapsed Similarly, it is a breach of fiduciary duty if a former fiduciary solicits the former employer's exclusive suppliers to switch their allegiance to supply a business until a reasonable period of time has passed. What is a reasonable length of time for fiduciary duties to persist is determined on a case-by-case basis.[99]

The motions judge found as a fact that the Plaintiff had a fiduciary relationship with firm. The Plaintiff had access to sensitive, confidential and proprietary information about the firm's business, its workplace, and its overall affairs. He had confidential information about suppliers' discounts and information about the pricing of materials and items in the context of complex construction projects and he knew the details of the firm's relationships with various subcontractors and suppliers. From time to time during his tenure with the firm, the Plaintiff was involved in preparing bids for projects and was privy to confidential internal budget information and pricing methodology.[100]

The motions judge observed that in certain circumstances, a defendant may set off his or her liquidated or unliquidated claim against the plaintiff's claim. Equitable setoff is available where: (1) the defendant can show some equitable ground for being protected against the plaintiff's demands; (2) the equitable ground must go to the very root of the plaintiff's claim; (3) the setoff must be clearly connected with the plaintiff's demand that it would be manifestly unjust to allow the plaintiff to enforce payment without taking into consideration the cross-claim; and (4) the plaintiff's claim and the setoff need not arise out of the same contract. However, the motions judge concluded that there was no genuine issue requiring a trial that the Plaintiff breached his fiduciary duties. The Plaintiff's new employer was entitled to compete with the firm for business in Ontario, and there was nothing unfair or improper in the Plaintiff's recruitment of several employees of the firm that left the firm to work with ENGIE. The Plaintiff did not use any confidential or proprietary information from the firm while he was at ENGIE. There was no substance to the firm's breach of fiduciary duty setoff claim and there were no genuine issues requiring a trial.[101]

On appeal in Cosolo v. Geo. A. Kelson Company Limited,[102] the appellant argued that the motion judge made palpable and overriding errors in finding that Cosolo did not breach his fiduciary duty by communicating with two current Kelson employees and that even if he did, the communications were meaningless breaches.[103]

The Court of Appeal rejected the appellant's submission that a breach of fiduciary duty case such as this was in a special category that is not suitable for summary judgment, and therefore the motion judge should have declined to act on the evidence put before the court on the summary judgment motion. Instead he should have ordered a trial, or possibly one or more mini-trials, with full documentary discovery. The motion judge's conclusion that the respondent breached no fiduciary duty owed to his employer causing damage was amply supported by the evidence. There was nothing raised in the cross-examinations on the affidavits to suggest the need for any further exploration of either documentary or testimonial evidence to resolve any of the issues that the motion judge was asked to decide. There was no genuine issue for trial raised on the record. A breach of fiduciary duty is not a special category that is not amenable to summary judgment where no genuine issue for trial is raised.[104]

In Dillon v. Dillon Hillstead Melanson C.G.A. Prof. Corp.,[105] DHM commenced an action against Gord Dillon and Mike Dillon for conspiracy to breach fiduciary obligations. Mike Dillon was terminated from his employment with DHM. In addition to being an employee, Mike Dillon was one of the shareholders and directors of DHM. Immediately upon his termination, Mike Dillon took no further role in the operation or management of DHM. In July 2010, Gordon Dillon, a former partner in the predecessor to DHM, came out of retirement and set up a new accounting firm. Shortly after Gord Dillon opened his new firm, a substantial number of clients from DHM switched their business to Gord Dillon's firm and three former employees of DHM commenced employment at Gord Dillon's firm. DHM formed the belief that Gord Dillon and Mike Dillon were working together in the new firm.[106]

There is an existing cause of action in Saskatchewan for conspiracy to breach fiduciary obligations. The court observed that it was important at the outset to recognize that Gord Dillon owed no fiduciary obligations to DHM. Gord Dillon had not practised accounting for four and one half years at the point when he again began practicing, well beyond the three year term of the restrictive covenant contained in the Withdrawal Agreement and also beyond the reach of any fiduciary obligations owed by Gord Dillon. There were no restrictions of any kind on Gord Dillon re-entering the practice of accounting in Regina, taking clients from DHM or hiring staff away from DHM. Gord Dillon's only potential liability came from a claim that he conspired with Mike Dillon to breach Mike Dillon's fiduciary obligation.[107]

The court first had to determine what fiduciary obligations, if any, were owed by Mike Dillon to DHM. As of June 30, 2010, Mike Dillon was a senior management employee who had been terminated for cause. At the time of his termination, he was also a director of DHM. The court observed that it is well settled that a senior management employee or a director of a corporation owes a fiduciary obligation to his former employer or the corporation he is or was a director of. Mike Dillon was not subject to a non-competition or non-solicitation agreement, but his fiduciary obligations existed even in the absence of such a contract. This fiduciary obligation does not exist only if the employee, officer or director resigns or retires. It may also continue if such a person involuntarily leaves. A fiduciary obligation does not continue, or at least is significantly reduced, if an employee is wrongfully dismissed. The fiduciary duty, however, will continue if the employee is terminated for cause. The continuation of a fiduciary duty upon termination for cause will continue because the former employer is not in breach of the contract of employment or its duties owed to the employee. Such a rule avoids the mischief of an employee who wishes to depart from engaging in behaviour which leaves the employer with no choice but to terminate the employee for cause which would then free the employee to breach his obligations in a manner harmful to the employer. If an employer has acted in good faith and upheld its end of the employment contract, the fiduciary obligation will continue.[108]

The trial judge concluded that Mike Dillon clearly owed a fiduciary obligation to DHM which continued after his termination for cause on June 30, 2010. He was a key management employee and a director of DHM. He had significant responsibilities and access to confidential and important information in these roles. However, not every action taken by Mike Dillon that had a connection to DHM's former clients, employees of DHM or the operation of Gord Dillon's new business would result in a breach of Mike Dillon's fiduciary obligations. While DHM was highly suspicious that Mike Dillon and Gord Dillon were working in concert in an effort to take DHM's employees and clients, DHM failed to prove any of the following: a. Any contact between Mike Dillon and DHM's current or former employees after June 30, 2010 and before the former employees commenced working for Gord Dillon; b. Any contact between Mike Dillon and any clients or former clients of DHM between June 30, 2010 and July 1, 2011; c. Any accounting work done for any of DHM's former clients, or for any other client, by Mike Dillon between June 30, 2010 and July 1, 2011; d. Any solicitation of DHM's clients by Mike Dillon at any point in time after June 30, 2010, despite over four years having passed since his termination; e. Any communication of any kind between Mike Dillon and Gord Dillon regarding the solicitation of DHM's clients or enticement of DHM's employees; f. The provision of any of DHM's confidential information or client lists from Mike Dillon to Gord Dillon; g. The use of any of DHM's confidential information or client lists by Mike Dillon or Gord Dillon; and h. Any communications between Mike Dillon and Gord Dillon whereby Gord Dillon induced or encouraged Mike Dillon to breach any agreements or duties with DHM. Accordingly, DHM failed to prove Mike Dillon solicited clients, enticed employees away from DHM, used confidential information or provided confidential information to Gord Dillon. The actions taken by Mike Dillon subsequent to his termination did not constitute a breach of fiduciary obligations. The assistance provided to Gord Dillon in setting up his office in the summer of 2010 did not involve the use of any confidential information or involve activities directly related to any of DHM's clients. The fact of Mike Dillon subsequently working as a staff accountant for Gord Dillon one year after his termination, using his skills and knowledge to provide accounting services to some of the same clients he serviced at DHM did not constitute a breach of his fiduciary obligation. With regard to the alleged conspiracy, there was no evidence of any communications or plans between Mike Dillon and Gord Dillon for Gord Dillon to use information obtained from Mike Dillon in breach of his fiduciary obligations. There was no breach simply as a result of Gord Dillon taking staff and clients directly from DHM. While the circumstances and timing of Gord Dillon's new accounting practice coming into existence were suspicious, the setting up of a new office by Gord Dillon, and the exodus of clients and staff, was not, on its own, capable of proving a breach of fiduciary obligations by Mike Dillon.[109]

The trial judge observed that the onus was on DHM to prove the breach, but noted that DHM did not call any of the independent witnesses who had direct knowledge of the activities allegedly engaged in by Mike Dillon and Gord Dillon. None of the three former DHM employees were called as witnesses by DHM to testify about what they observed in the office from July 2010 to July 2011. These witnesses were all well known to DHM, worked on a daily basis in Gord Dillon's new office and would have been able to provide independent testimony regarding the presence and activities of Mike Dillon in Gord Dillon's new office, but none of them were called to testify. Likewise, DHM was well aware of the names and addresses of all 70 clients that transferred their business to Gord Dillon's new firm, but none of them were called to testify. Again, the former clients had no vested interest in the outcome of the matter and could have provided evidence regarding whether or not they were solicited by Mike Dillon. None of DHM's witnesses had any knowledge of any contact by Mike Dillon with his former clients, any accounting work done by Mike Dillon for those clients or any contact with the staff. The court was left with the uncontradicted evidence of Mike Dillon and Gord Dillon which established the absence of a breach of a fiduciary obligation by Mike Dillon.[110]

Absent wrongful conduct, a fiduciary will almost always be allowed to compete immediately with his or her former employer. It is not mere competition that is a breach of fiduciary duty.[111] Further, the fiduciary employee will normally be free to advertise a new business and to accept business from customers of the former employer.[112] By way of example, in 309925 Ontario Ltd. v. Tyrrell,[113] the court acknowledged that:

It must be kept in mind in looking at the factors present, in any case, that employers are, or should be aware, that customers of a business who have the benefit of good advice, skill and attention of an employee such as the defendant, tend to seek out his services as opposed to those of other employees. Where such an employee changes employment and becomes a competitor, it is not unusual to find former satisfied customers bringing their business to his new location. Even a senior management employee has the right, in the absence of agreement, or statutory restriction, to enter business in direct competition with his former employer and to advertise the change, including the availability of his services.

Some cases, such as the previously cited case of W.J. Christie & Co. v. Greer,[114] have made it clear that, in some circumstances, a fiduciary employee will even be allowed to solicit the former employer's customers, so long as there is no misuse of trade secrets and customer lists.

In terms of the obligation of all employees not to misuse confidential information of the former employer, the courts have held that trade secrets and customer lists are confidential. However, there is some ambiguity as to whether “confidential information” includes the names of such customers, and their needs and preferences, that the employee has learned during his period of service and can recall. In Parrish & Heimbecker Ltd. v. Delmar Commodities Ltd.,[115] the plaintiff sought from both Hodgson and Delmar return of its confidential information and an injunction enjoining them from using such confidential information or soliciting its customers, particularly in an area of Manitoba described as the “northeast territory”. The defendant Hodgson was employed by the plaintiff until September 6, 2011 when he went to work for Delmar, a supplier and competitor of the plaintiff. In the winter of 2010/11, Delmar decided that because the plaintiff had chosen not to extend its reach into the northeast territory with a facility in the area, it would do so. It entered into an agreement to acquire land and engaged local contractors to do the construction work. Delmar did not advise the plaintiff of its intention to build this facility until after Hodgson had joined the company. On September 6, 2011, Hodgson resigned from his employment with the plaintiff. He had sought out other employment and as a result secured two offers, one from Delmar for the position of Territory Manager for Eastern Manitoba. He took the job and began work shortly thereafter. Hodgson denied that he took any customer list or other property of the plaintiff when he left its employ. The plaintiff had no evidence that he took any such documentation. There was no formal employment contract between Hodgson and the plaintiff, although he did endorse his acknowledgement on the plaintiff's employee handbook which contained a provision obliging all employees to maintain in strict confidence information received by the plaintiff or its customers and requiring them not to disclose this information either during the period of employment or at any time thereafter.[116]

The motions judge observed that there was limited, if any, evidence of Hodgson having or using confidential information of the plaintiff. There was no evidence that he had any documentation belonging to the plaintiff, including customer lists. He had no secret information about pricing of Legend Seed, as all sellers were required to sell at the same price. There was no evidence that he had targeted the plaintiff's customers. The names of all farmers in the area were public information.[117]

It was possible that, at trial, Hodgson would not be found to have been a key employee. However, the evidence was quite convincing that he was. As General Manager, he was more than a sales manager. He had general managerial responsibilities over a large facility with a substantial sales volume. In terms of his reassignment to Customer Service Manager, he held this position for only the last two or three months of his employment with the plaintiff. In both positions, he acquired considerable knowledge about the plaintiff's customers.[118] If Hodgson did no more than pass on his business card and advise of where he was working, it was possible that, at trial, this might be found not to constitute solicitation. However, this seemed unlikely. By personally attending at the farms, Hodgson had clearly done more than generally advertise his new employment. He directly approached farmers, knowing that some of them were customers of the plaintiff, in an attempt to secure their business. And he has successfully concluded sales with some of these individuals.

However, the plaintiff had not established that it would suffer irreparable harm if the injunction were denied. The court was not persuaded that the plaintiff's customers were moving to Delmar because of any solicitation on the part of Hodgson. Instead, any loss of market share would appear to result from Delmar now selling Legend Seed and having a facility in the area and, probably even more importantly, from the plaintiff's decision to no longer sell Legend Seed.

The balance of convenience weighed in favour of denying an injunction. The reality was that the sale of soybean seeds was a highly competitive business. While Delmar hired Hodgson to assist in its entry into the northeast territory market, there was scant evidence that it or Hodgson was using confidential information or targeting the plaintiff's customers. Further, even if Hodgson was a key employee of the plaintiff, the law provides that he could join a competitor, sell to its customers, and advertise.[119]

The courts have sometimes concluded that where an employer's business is set up in a manner that creates close working relationships between an employee and customers, the employer runs the risk that if the employee departs, the customers will end up transferring their business to that employee.

However, cases such as Hudson's Bay Co. v. McClocklin[120] demonstrate how precarious this area of the law can be. While the Hudson's Bay case was decided on the basis of unique facts, it held that the hearing aid specialist of a department store was a fiduciary.[121]

Some courts have been more specific in defining the steps that can be taken by a fiduciary. In Moore International (Canada) Ltd. v. Carter,[122] the British Columbia Supreme Court held that departed fiduciary employees cannot specifically solicit customers of their former employer. Rather, any solicitation must be general in nature, to the public as a whole. There is no absolute prohibition against a fiduciary sending out promotional materials or generally advertising a new business. The prohibition is against actively soliciting the business of specific customers for a reasonable period of time after termination of employment.[123]

In considering whether a former employee was a “key employee” for the purpose of attracting a fiduciary duty, the court will look at a former employee's job duties; the extent or frequency of contact between the employee and customers and/or suppliers; whether the employee was the primary contact with customers and/or suppliers; to what extent the employee had access and made use of knowledge of the former employee's customers, their accounts, pricing practices and the pricing of product and services; and to what extent the former employee's information was confidential. In Canadian Hedge Watch Inc. v. Street,[124] the plaintiff was granted an interlocutory order prohibiting the defendants from using the plaintiff's confidential information; soliciting or accepting business from the current and prospective sponsors, clients, and attendees of the plaintiff's conference; usurping, taking, or converting any corporate assets or opportunities belonging to the plaintiff; unfairly competing with the plaintiff; interfering with the plaintiff's contractual relations with third parties; misrepresenting that they are associated with the plaintiff or its conferences; and, from arranging, presenting, promoting, sponsoring, or hosting The Alliance for Institutional Dialogue's “Annual Symposium” in Niagara-on-the-Lake, or elsewhere, and/or any conference of the same or a similar nature in southern Ontario.[125]

The plaintiff was a commercial entity that ran conferences as a revenue-generating business activity. It had established goodwill in its conference. The defendant, Street, had been the Vice President of Sales of the plaintiff since 2009. She became the Chief Operating Officer of the NID Conference upon its creation in 2010. Street resigned from the plaintiff's employ in 2013 in order to spend more time with her husband and possibly to help him produce practice management conferences in his business. However, she agreed to continue to consult to the plaintiff on a part-time basis under the terms of a written consulting agreement in relation to the NID Conference. As COO of the NID Conference Street was also a member of the Advisory Board. She was the representative of the plaintiff with principal responsibility for running the conference. Together with the defendants Lett and Holt, Street was very successful in developing the NID Conference to its premier place in the industry. There was a strong prima facie case that under a veil of secrecy the defendants agreed to and proceeded to unlawfully take the plaintiff's corporate assets and its corporate opportunities associated with those assets. At a time when the defendant Street was contractually bound to diligently and faithfully serve the plaintiff, she and the other defendants agreed to take the plaintiff's conference goodwill and opportunity. Rather than competing openly and honestly, there was a strong prima facie case, from the defendants' own evidence, that the defendants surreptitiously carried out overt acts to implement their agreement to take the plaintiff's conference.[126]

The motions judge concluded that there was at least one serious issue to be tried as to whether Street was a fiduciary in light of her acknowledged significance as the face of the plaintiff in respect of the NID Conference. She had “encyclopedic knowledge” of the plaintiff's business, market opportunity, customers, and suppliers. If Street was a fiduciary, then she fell under the prohibition against unfair post-employment competition. An important factor in deciding whether a fiduciary's competition is unfair is whether it is infected by improper conduct prior to the time that the fiduciary left her role with the employer. The defendants had met, agreed to their plan, took the hotel reservations, and prepared to commence sales as if they were the NID Conference before Street even left the plaintiff. They incorporated the corporate defendant one week later with Street as a director. Under cross-examination the defendants agreed that Street's appointment to the board was intentionally done but was reversed later purportedly at Street's request. The motions judge observed that her appointment was an “error” only in the sense that Street realized that she should not have done it. It was not accidental.[127]

The other defendants all knew and participated in Street's conduct. The motions judge noted that a subordinate who participates in a fiduciary's breach of duty is liable with the fiduciary. In this case, arguably, it was the other defendants who were the seniors members of the new entity who wished to create a business and induced a subordinate who had duties to the plaintiff to join them and to breach her duties in doing so. Holt and Lett never resigned from the plaintiff's Advisory Board. While there was no doubt that Holt and Lett were free to compete with the plaintiff generally, there was at least a serious issue to be tried as to whether in agreeing to sit on the plaintiff's Advisory Board for consideration there was an implied duty that Holt and Lett would act in the best interests of the plaintiff and avoid conflicts of interest vis-à-vis the subject matter of their appointment and not try to usurp the conference for themselves. The defendants Holt and Lett argued that they could not be fiduciaries because they never undertook to sacrifice their interests to protect those of the plaintiff. The question of whether by agreeing to join the plaintiff's Advisory Board, the defendants undertook such duties to the plaintiff in relation to the NID Conference was a serious issue to be tried.[128]

In Innersolutions Ltd. v. Hooper,[129] the Applicant sought injunctive relief to prohibit the Respondents from operating a directly competing business, soliciting and using the Applicant's trade connections, soliciting and providing services to any of the Applicant's clients, and disclosing and using the Applicant's confidential information.[130]

The Applicant provided a specialized counselling program that included psychotherapy and education services to individuals suffering from severe mental illnesses, as well as to their families. The Respondents Hooper and Woolsey were former employees or independent contractors of the Applicant. Woolsey and Hooper incorporated Inspired Minds Inc. while they were working for the Applicant. The Applicant hired Woolsey in April 2007 and Hooper in April 2012. The Applicant required Woolsey and Hooper to sign agreements, which stated that they would learn the design and operation of the Applicant's DBT program, they would provide treatment using that program, and the Applicant had interests that it wanted to protect. Each agreement required that they not compete for business, clients, or professional services during their employment and that they provide three months' notice of termination. Hooper's agreement included additional express terms that all patients were to remain with the Applicant in the event of her termination and she would not offer or advertise private practice services in the specialized nature of the Applicant within a four hundred kilometer radius of Calgary for twenty-four months from the date of termination. Woolsey's agreement also required that all clients were to have the first option to remain with the Applicant in the event of her termination. In June 2012, Woolsey and her husband wanted to explore the possibility of purchasing the Applicant's business. To facilitate this exploration, they signed a confidentiality/non-competition agreement.[131]

The modified first branch of the test for an interlocutory injunction required the Court to consider whether the Applicant had established a strong prima facie case that the restrictions were enforceable against the Respondents. This was the Applicant's onus and the Court found that although the Applicant had a proprietary interest that was worthy of protection, there was insufficient evidence that would allow the Court fully to assess the reasonableness of the restrictive covenant it was seeking against the Respondents. That was not to say that such evidence was not available. It simply meant that the Applicant had not met its onus on the motion.[132]

The motions judge found that the agreements that bound the respondents were too broad or ambiguous which pointed to their unreasonableness. The Applicant argued that either or both of Hooper and Woolsey had fiduciary duties towards the Applicant. The motions judge observed that there is no doubt that a director and officer of corporation acts in a fiduciary capacity towards the corporation. Fiduciary obligations can extend beyond those roles. Although the Applicant provided the respondents with certain confidential information, they did not have the authority to affect the Applicant's “legal and economic interests”. They did, however, have exclusive access to certain of the Applicant's clients. The motions judge stated:
But does that place them in a fiduciary relationship vis-á-vis the Applicant? In WJ Christie & Co v Greer (1981), 121 DLR (3d) 472 at 477 (Man CA), the Manitoba Court of Appeal said the following:

There is nothing to prevent an ordinary employee from terminating his employment, and normally that employee is free to compete with his former employer. The right to compete freely may be constrained by contract…. But it is different for a director/officer/key management person who occupies a fiduciary position. Upon his resignation and departure, that person is entitled to accept business from former client, but direct solicitation of that business is not permissible. Having accepted a position of trust, the individual is not entitled to allow his own self-interest to collide and conflict with fiduciary responsibilities. The direct solicitation of former clients traverses the boundary of acceptable conduct….[133]

The motions judge concluded that it did not appear that the respondents were “key employees” or “key management”. At best, they were “ordinary employees”. Thus, they were “free to compete with the Applicant. That was not to say that with more evidence a court might find that they were key employees. That issue would be left to the trial judge.[134]

With respect to a duty of fidelity and good faith to his employer, a duty much narrower in scope than the duty owed by a departing employee who stands in the position of a fiduciary, the respondents gave the clients an option to stay with the Applicant. Further, on their departure from the Applicant's employ, they shredded their patient lists and left the patient files with the Applicant. Again, further evidence might be extracted during the trial that might provide more information concerning a breach of their duty of fidelity and good faith, but such information was simply not before the motions judge.[135]

In IT/Net Inc. v. Doucette,[136] the court considered whether an enforceable non-competition or non-solicitation clause also brings an obligation “to reject or resist offers” from the employer's customers. The plaintiff argued that there was not only “a prohibition against actively seeking business from your former employer's customers, but also, in addition, there is a duty to decline unsolicited offers which may come your way.”[137]
The plaintiff relied on the case of DiFlorio v. Con Structural Steel Ltd.[138] After reviewing the facts, the court stated:

In discussing the distinction between passively attracting former customers to a new business, and actively approaching them to get their business, the trial judge had this to say at paragraph 205 at page 43:

The extent of the fiduciary duty and the question as to whether there has been breach of such a duty would differ with the factual situations in each individual case. If [a former employee], by reason of his own qualifications and abilities attracts customers to his new business, such a result accrues from a personal asset of [the former employee]. On the other hand, if [the former employee] acquires a connection or a relationship with a customer of the [former employer] during the course of his employment with the [former employer] and, after his resignation, he affirmatively approaches that customer with a view of enticing the customer to cease doing business with the [former employer], that would be an act which would pass over the boundary and constitute breach of a fiduciary duty.
The trial judge eventually found in favour of the plaintiffs, based on the particular facts present in the case, as expressed as follows at paragraphs 216 and 217 at page 46:

In these circumstances, I conclude that the non-solicitation obligation of Roland and Bertolo precluded them from quoting on a project in response to a contact that may have been initiated by a former Rocca client in light of the generalized solicitation that is admitted to have taken place. As employees of Con Steel, Bertolo and Roland were entitled to compete vigorously and head-to-head for new clients. However, the “stranger principle” would be violated if, on the facts of this case, Con Steel were permitted to exploit Bertolo's relationships with former Rocca clients simply because direct contact may have been initiated by those clients after Con Steel's generalized solicitation in this small community.

I conclude that an overly rigid view of what constitutes solicitation is not appropriate in the facts of this case. That conclusion is reinforced by the decision of Chapnik J. in Sure-Grip Fasteners v. Allgrade Bolt & Chain, supra at 291 (C.C.E.L.). She confirms that, when there has been direct solicitation of former customers in the business community, it is not important to ascertain subsequently whether the former client requested a price quotation from the fiduciary:

Clearly, the defendants set out, to establish their own business by gaining customers cultivated and nourished, if not nurtured, while in the plaintiffs employ. Their business diligence was utilized for the most part to pursue the plaintiff's customers, in an attempt to create a diversion of business to their own company. King himself contacted 40 to 50 former customers during the first week after his departure.

The defendants could have chosen to allow news of their departure and the establishment of Allgrade to reach the plaintiffs customers without resort to the direct approach. Accordingly, whether or not the quotations on orders were requested by any or all of the common customers, in the particular circumstances here, I have no hesitation in finding the actions of the defendants to have been in breach of their fiduciary responsibility to the plaintiff.

The Ontario Court of Appeal upheld the trial judge's decision that, based on the facts of the case, there was no breach of a non-solicitation clause. The court emphasized that it “should not be taken as saying that the non-solicitation clause in issue is unenforceable”, only that “the facts as found by the trial judge do not constitute a breach”.[139]
The Ontario decision of White Oaks Welding Supplies v. Tapp[140] also held that fiduciaries are prevented from directly and deliberately soliciting the customers of their former employer:

The obligation of [the defendant] was of an altogether higher nature and was to refrain, not from competition, but from deliberately soliciting customers of the plaintiff, other than as part of the general customer public to whom general solicitation might be made.

However, in Eversoft Fibre & Foam Ltd. v. James, the court, relying heavily on Canadian Aero Service Limited v. O'Malley,[141] disagreed with the contention “that it is quite proper and fair to advertise [a] new business, and that if it results in customers of the Plaintiff choosing [the former employee's] business over that of the Plaintiff, that is no breach”.[142] On the other hand, Axiom Services Ltd. v. Weigert,[143] the court held:

Generally, however, such duties will not include a duty not to compete with the former employer, nor will they prohibit the former employee from attempting to woo the existing clients of the former employer …
Numerous cases, both allowing and prohibiting various kinds of solicitation, have considered this issue.[144]
